labels.name: wontfix

issues.title: Make non-essential fields optional
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
The JSON makes four fields mandatory.  If the resolver operator is in the registry, then you really only need their identity (for looking up the URL template) and the incident code (to add to the resolver identity for use in the template).  The authority and description are details that can be provided at the URL.

Given that, and given the i18n shortcomings of a static JSON format, I'd suggest making the authority and description fields optional.

issues.title: Which error code is it?
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
The current version says:

> In typical use, a DNS query that is filtered might contain an Extended DNS Error Code 17 (see [RFC8914]) and an EXTRA-TEXT [...]

That code is "Filtered".  But I think that the rule could probably be any of the following (from RFC 8914):

* 4.16. Extended DNS Error Code 15 - Blocked
* 4.17. Extended DNS Error Code 16 - Censored
* 4.18. Extended DNS Error Code 17 - Filtered

The extent to which the difference between these codes is important (and how much the server can reveal) doesn't seem important.

Also, given how each code is relatively short, perhaps this could include the name as well.  My reaction to seeing this was "well, of *course* it's code 17, *everyone* knows what code 17 means".

comments.author: Shiw5656
comments.body:
The current text only mentions Extended DNS Error (EDE) Code 17 ("Filtered"), but RFC 8914 also defines related codes:

Code 15: "Blocked"
Code 16: "Censored"
Code 17: "Filtered"
Since the distinction between these codes might not always be critical, it would be helpful to list all three for clarity. Additionally, including both the code number and name (e.g., "15 (Blocked), 16 (Censored), or 17 (Filtered)") makes the meaning clearer without requiring readers to look up RFC 8914.

pulls.title: Definition lists FTW
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body: I've used a compact form for the registrations so that there is a visual separation.  Otherwise, it looks like one registration.
